awd_titl_txt: Genome Assembly and Analysis of the Bloom Forming Southern Ocean Salp, Salpa Thompsoni
awd_abstract_narration:
The Antarctic salp, Salpa thompsoni, is a gelatinous zooplankton that is an important member in the Southern Ocean pelagic ecosystem. Field studies have documented rapid population growth under favorable environmental conditions, resulting in dense blooms of salps that substantially change the pelagic ecosystem in regards to both structure and processes.  Because this zooplankton can proliferate rapidly and it is not readily consumed by upper trophic levels, its periodic dominance has the potential to drastically chance ecosystem energetics as well as change material export to the deep ocean.  Completion of a comprehensive reference genome for the Antarctic salp will enable the identification of genes and gene networks underlying physiological responses and allow detection of potential processes driving natural selection and the species? adaptation strategies to the Antarctic Environment.  Comparative genomic analysis will add the dimension of time to inferences about organismal adaptation and allow consideration of their potential to adapt to future environmental changes, and will allow examination of novel aspects of genomic evolution found only in the invertebrate class Tunicata. The completed salp reference genome will provide a valuable foundational resource for other scientists working on this species as well as the genomic basis for function and adaptation in the Antarctic. 



The primary goal of this effort is to examine the rapid genome evolution characteristic of this tunicate species and examine the genomic bases of the species? potential for adaptation, and specifically the role of flexible gene networks for successful responses to changing environmental conditions. The primary hypothesis driving this research is that predicted S. thompsoni orthologs (i.e., genes of the same function that share a common ancestor) that show evidence of rapid evolution are indicative of positive selection, and further that these genes and associated gene networks provide the basis for rapid adaptation of the Antarctic salp to environmental variation associated with a changing ocean. The proposed genome assembly strategy will allow further refinements and scaffolding of the current, highly fragmented genome assembly using the methods developed during previous work. Specimens of S. thompsoni now archived at UConn will be analyzed to improve the salp genome assembly, increasing overall scaffold length, and decreasing the number of total contigs.  High-quality reference assemblies will be obtained with two high-output paired-end sequencing runs (Illumina) on a single individual, coupled with three runs on the Oxford Nanopore long-read sequencer. The same sequencing strategy will be performed on a sub-sampling of tissues from the same specimen to produce a very high quality reference transcriptome, which will allow for high quality gene models and near-complete gene predictions in the genome assembly. Comparisons with available genomic data for Urochordate and Cephalochordate species will increase the number of orthologs analyzed. Orthologous genes will be tested for evidence of rapid selection in the salp lineage, and the results will be compared to published expression profiles and ontology functions for the salp. All data will be made publicly available via existing web portals; a project website will be developed to disseminate research results for access by the both research and educational communities. Website design will use a local instance of jbrowse that will offer annotations, downloadable data files, and tracts of previously-published datasets.

por.por_cntn:
Salps (Phylum Chordata, Subphylum Tunicata, Class Thaliacea) are abundant and important members of the pelagic assemblage; the complex life history with alternating sexual and asexual stages contributes to rapid bloom formation. In the Southern Ocean, Salpa thompsoni blooms are becoming more frequent and dense, potentially disrupting ecosystem function by out-competing the keystone species, the Antarctic krill, Euphausia superba. A primary goal of our project was to identify the genomic features that define the species and support bloom formation. 

Genomic resources for the Tunicata are overall lacking, with only 18 out of >2,000 known species having assembled genomes. To date, the S. thompsoni is the only pelagic tunicate with an available reference genome, which was determined by an earlier NSF award to the lead investigators (Jue et al., 2017; NSF-1044982), although the assembly is both incomplete and fragmented due to the short-read DNA sequencing technologies available at the time.

The new results from this project for the genome assembly and annotation for S. thompsoni are marked improvements over previous efforts. This study used new state-of-the-art sequencing platforms and approaches, including Oxford Nanopore (ONT) long-read sequencing and de novo assembly, to determine an improved assembly for S. thompsoni and an additional assembly for S. aspera. Both genomes uncovered an 80% repeat abundance, 20% higher than predicted, and the highest of all reported tunicate species. Further genome analysis revealed an abundance of G-quadruplex motifs (i.e., highly stable secondary structures linked to repetitive genomic regions) distributed around genes and repeats.

Our subsequent analyses revealed large stretches of G-quadruplex sequences that were extremely frequent throughout both the S. thompsoni and S. aspera genomes. The extraordinarily high repeat content and high frequency of G-quadruplex secondary structures presented significant challenges for DNA sequencing using the ONT technology. As part of trouble-shooting to obtain high-quality genomic data, we compared the genomic landscape of G-quadruplexes of S. thompsoni with that of other tunicate species. These structures are known to serve important biological roles in local gene regulation and genome stability in many species, and we now hypothesize that they serve an important adaptive function for salps, and are essential for regulating their complex life histories with alternating sexual and asexual stages.

In addition to genomic references, a reference transcriptome from varied life stages was developed for S. thompsoni. Transcriptomes represent RNA molecules, which can be informative in understanding gene functions specific to certain cell types or life history events, including genes and pathways required for the complex life history key to salp bloom formation. Differential expression analysis identified genes responsible for male sex differentiation and spermatogenesis in early life stages, in conjunction with expression of genes related to female reproduction, suggesting that salps are hermaphroditic and challenging the traditional view of protogynous hermaphroditism. This novel finding suggests a molecular mechanism supporting and regulating salp population blooms, which may also allow new avenues and approaches to providing better predictions for bloom formation of salps.

Studying the genomes of marine organisms has benefits beyond fundamental research on basic biological functions. Comparison of genomes within and between species and populations can reveal important evolutionary history and adaptation to different environments. Genomics-based studies have been influential in aiding conservation management and policy decisions by informing species identification, degree of hybridization, population diversity, and effective population sizes. Genomics aids aquaculture by identifying gene variants associated with health, disease resistance, feed resistance, environmental tolerance, and growth. Genomics of marine species also supports discoveries with benefits to human health advancements, such as the identification of natural products that have been used in anti-infectives, anti-bacterials, anti-cancer agents, anti-diabetic agents, and insecticides.

The creation of new genomic and transcriptomic resources for salps during this project has identified major gaps in our knowledge of their reproduction, led to new understanding of the underlying determinants and drivers of their complex life history, and provided new tools for predicting salp population blooms. Advancements in third-generation DNA and RNA sequencing are continuing to yield new opportunities for genome and transcriptome sequencing of non-model species, such as salps, and opening new doors for understanding and predicting processes, patterns, and dynamics of ocean ecosystems.
